Getting The Elektra Software
Elektra was formerly named Linux Registry, so many links will still take you to "Linux Registry" named pages. They'll change over time.
The Elektra Initiative software and info can be found at elektra.sf.net and (in all) the following places:
C source and RPMs from sourceforge.net Subversion repository, thanks to Sean Russel Wiki space, made available by Daniel Lambea Freshmeat project page Advogato project page Orkut Community
Subscribe to general discussions list or see the list archives
There is an OpenOffice.org presentation [HTML without animations] that anybody can deliver in community events, to help create awareness about the Elektra Initiative. There is also a german translation by Markus Raab.
To get the last snapshot from Subversion do the following: bash:~$ cd src bash:~/src$ svn co http://germane-software.com/repositories/elektra/trunk elektra bash:~/src$ cd elektra bash:~/src/elektra$ # files are here
Elektra has a BSD license.
Online Manual Pages and API Documentation
Elektra man pages can be accessed online:
kdb.1: The kdb command man page. Describes the usage of the command used to administer Elektra's key database. You don't need it if you are already reading this. elektra.7: Discussion about what is the Elektra Initiative etc. You don't need it if you are already reading this. elektra.5: Elektra internals. kdb.3: C API documentation for the KeyDB class. Browse the doxygen instead. key.3: C API documentation for the Key class. Browse the doxygen instead. keyset.3: C API documentation for the KeySet class. Browse the doxygen instead.
You can also browse or download the API documentation (also provided in the -devel RPM), by Doxygen. It is complete, with many code examples.
Building an Ecosystem
The objective of the Elektra Initiative is to help create a pervasive, ubiquitous configuration system. This is an entire ecosystem, much more than a piece of code. This section lists the work of some people that joined the initiative and are helping to build this ecosystem.
Tools and Software Patches
Regedit GUI to edit the key database, using the QT library, by Gregor Burger. There is a Berlios entry with Subversion repository, and RPM packages available. Elektrified X.org [see README] to use a key database instead of xorg.conf file. Elektrified /sbin/init and Fedora Core 2 RPMs [see README] for the original sysvinit package from Miquel van Smoorenburg. Users and Groups Name System Module for GLibC, by Jens Andersen. This is a module that can be activated by the name system switch mechanism (/etc/nsswitch.conf) to let users and groups databases be Elektrified, instead of /etc/{passwd|shadow|groups}. Daniel Lambea and Israel Bethencourt are writing patches for basic system tools, and will have soon a full Elektrified Linux distribution.
Language Bindings and Packages
Ruby bindings, by Sean Russel. If you are writing code in Ruby, and need an easy way to store/retrieve configuration/state data, this is for you. Python bindings, by Scott Lemke. Lua bindings, by Rob King. Check also its README file.
JRegistry, by Alexopoulos Charalampos, are Java bindings for the Elektra API, and apparently a GUI for Elektra administration. Fedora Core RPM packages Gentoo ebuild, by Martin Holzhauer Arch Linux PKGBUILD, by Lukas Sabota, and also the Arch Linux binary packages.
All people working on that can be found on the Elektra mailling list.
Why Linux Needs to be Elektrified
Today's GNU/Linux systems (or other UNIX) are a sum of independent components collected in a bazar. Each of them already have a working, but selfish configuration system. Please read this section thinking about a system as a whole, not a sum of many parts.
The Elektra Initiative tries to upgrade a '1+1=2' system into a '1*1=1' one.
Look into /etc/fstab file. Now look into /etc/modules.conf, /etc/passwd, /etc/ssh/sshd_config, /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf. I see here two terrible problems:
They don't have a common file format.
Their location in the filesystem may be different from Linux distribution to distribution.
These 2 issues leverages other problems:
When two different softwares want to integrate themselves, it is programatically very hard to read, understand and correctly change its partner's configuration file. Think about installing a third-party video driver in XFree86, a new Apache plug-in, etc, and letting this new piece of software do the integration automatically, instead of the sysadmin vi the configuration file, understand and change it in the right way. So basic software integration is a pain today for ISVs (Independent Software Vendors).
A software developer must waste a lot of time to write the plumbing code for configuration file parsing etc. It is completelly out of his scope to write code to interoperate with other software's configurations files.
Different distributions tend to place different software configuration in different places with different formats. A regular SuSE system administrator, for example, will be lost when asked to work in a Debian or Slackware system. Think about the most primitive example: network configuration parameters. Each distro has its own approach.
A system administrator must know all these formats.
There is no way to know today what was changed in a specific configuration file. If /etc/shadow file time changes, there is no way to know if the change was related to nobody's or root's record.
High-level system administration GUIs (webmin, redhat-config-*, SuSE's YAST, etc) are just a dream today. They can never track successfully all the changes that happens in the format of the configuration files of such a rich diversity of Open Source software (httpd.conf, smb.conf, modules.conf, fstab, etc, etc, etc). The approach of some of them is to keep the configuration ideas in a private database and regenerate the specific configuration file whenever a change happens in this database. Welcome to the inconsistency nightmare.
Other OSes solved this problem by centralizing their configurations, and creating a framework to access them. Configurations then are no more represented by 'configuration files', but by key-value pairs organized in a structured tree commited to some naming convetions.
To achieve multi-vendor/provider consistent software integration, and ease of administration across heterogeneous Linux distributions, Linux needs a key-value pair mechanism to store its configurations.

Adoption by Legacy System Software
The benefits of Elektra will be felt only when configurations like those under /etc will move into it. It is expected that this will take time, but awareness should be raised in the community to speed the process.
Experienced Unix sysadmins seem (and were expected to be) sceptical about a key-value database on Linux, even when the Elektra Initiative tries to address other OSes registry's problems (centralization, security, consistency). But it is a truly required OS component from a good architecture perspective, and it can solve most of the Linux software integration issues, when adopted.
Elektra is expected to be adopted by developers of high-level software applications. Then by some Linux distribution specific admin tools, like redhat-config-network, then finally by main OS programs and libraries, like /sbin/init, PAM, /bin/mount, etc.

Virtual Screenshots
Elektra alone can't produce screenshots, because it is just a library/API as we saw above, but since everybody loves them, let's use some visual effects to show some of Elektra's concepts.
Hardware Status, Elektrified
This tree was generated by the hwconfKudzu-convert program that converts the /etc/sysconfig/hwconf file into Elektra's keys. In this example, we see that it detected a connected mouse. The keys under system/hw/byClass/MOUSE/GenericMousePS2psaux have all hardware properties detected by kudzu. There is also a system/hw/byBus tree that contains symbolic links to the byClass tree, to facilitate key access.
Filesystems Table, Elektrified
fstab-convert created this system/filesystems tree showed here, based on /etc/fstab. A unique identifier was calculated for each filesystem, and a key name generated. system/filesystems/mntwork is in evidence, showing the /mnt/work filesystem. Bellow, we can see standard key names for this filesystem properties. An example is system/filesystems/mntwork/mpoint that contains the value /mnt/work, or system/filesystems/mntwork/type that contains ext2.
X.Org Configurations Elektrified
All higher level software keys are located under system/sw, as showed above for XFree86 configuration. Pay attention to how easy it is to access and change XFree configuration, without any /etc/X11/XF86Config parsing effort, when using Elektra. XFree will look for its keys under system/sw/XFree/current which is a symbolic link to system/sw/XFree/handmade. This is an example on how the high level usage of symbolic links into the key database provides a lot of flexibility.
Easily Editing Elektra Keys
The kdb edit command provides an easy way to edit a group of keys using your prefered editor. It will dump the selected keys into an XML representation, and run the editor to let the user edit them. After user modifications, it will update, remove or include the keys based on the modified XML file. This real screenshot shows me using kate to modify the XFree configuration keys related to the monitor. If I didn't force it with the EDITOR environment, vi would be used.
Or you can use Gregor Burger's regedit GUI to edit keys very easily. Here is a screenshot editing the same above key.
Wanna Help The Elektra Initiative ?
We need a lot of help. The main software library is ready to be used, but we really need it to be used, so then in can become a standard.
Software Patches
We need patches for Modprobe, Samba, Apache, PAM etc to use Elektra, instead of /etc/modules.conf, /etc/smb.conf, /etc/httpd/httpd.conf, etc. Patches for system initialization scripts to use Elektra instead of /etc/sysconfig/*, /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/* files.
Marketing and Awareness
We need more participation in community events making presentations and advocating. There is an OpenOffice presentation entirelly commented that can be used. So if you have strong communication skills, think about making an Elektra presentation in an event close to your town.
Porting and Backends
Elektra needs platform specific storage backends to be written. For Linux, BSD and Unix, the current backend is fine. For Windows, a Registry storage backend is needed. Elektra needs to be ported, mainteined and packaged in other platforms. Windows, BSD, Mac, other Unix. Elektra binary packages and their maintainers are need for Slackware, Debian, SuSE Linux, Mandrake, etc. I provide Fedora/Red Hat RPMs.
Performance Improvements
Speed up reading and writing of keys is needed.
